009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.ellipse.algebraic;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
015
016import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
017import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
018import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition;
019
020/**
021 * <p>
022 * Algebraic ellipse fit based on Fitzgibbon's original method [1], as described
023 * in [2] (WITHOUT the additional numerical improvements). Based on generalized
024 * symmetric eigenproblem solution. See [3, Sec. 11.2.1] for a detailed
025 * description. Note: This implementation does not use data centering nor
026 * accepts a specific reference point. With exactly 5 input points (generally
027 * sufficient for ellipse fitting) the scatter matrix X is singular and thus the
028 * Cholesky decomposition used by the
029 * {@link GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition} cannot be applied. Thus at
030 * least 6 distinct input points are required (i.e., no duplicate points are
031 * allowed).
032 * </p>
033 * <p>
034 * [1] A. W. Fitzgibbon, M. Pilu, and R. B. Fisher. Direct least- squares
035 * fitting of ellipses. IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine
036 * Intelligence 21(5), 476-480 (1999). <br>
037 * [2] R. Halíř and J. Flusser. Numerically stable direct least squares fitting
038 * of ellipses. In "Proceedings of the 6th International Conference in Central
039 * Europe on Computer Graphics and Visualization (WSCG’98)", pp. 125-132, Plzeň,
040 * CZ (February 1998). <br>
041 * [3] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
042 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
043 * </p>
044 * 
045 * @author WB
046 * @version 2022/11/17
047 */
048public class EllipseFitFitzgibbonOriginal implements EllipseFitAlgebraic {
049        
050        // constraint matrix
051        // constraint matrix
052        private static final RealMatrix C = Matrix.makeRealMatrix(6, 6,
053                                0, 0, 2, 0, 0, 0,
054                                0,-1, 0, 0, 0, 0,
055                                2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
056                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
057                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0,
058                                0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0 );
059
060        private final double[] q;       // = (A,B,C,D,E,F) algebraic ellipse parameters
061        
062        public EllipseFitFitzgibbonOriginal(Pnt2d[] points) {
063                if (points.length < 6) {
064                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("fitter requires at least 6 sample points instead of " + points.length);
065                }
066                this.q = fit(points);
067        }
068
069        @Override
070        public double[] getParameters() {
071                return this.q;
072        }
073        
074        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] points) {
075                final int n = points.length;
076
077                // design matrix X:
078                RealMatrix X = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(n, 6);
079                
080                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
081                        double x = points[i].getX();
082                        double y = points[i].getY();
083                        double[] ri = {sqr(x), x * y, sqr(y), x, y, 1};
084                        X.setRow(i, ri);
085                }
086                
087                // scatter matrix S:
088                RealMatrix S = X.transpose().multiply(X);
089
090                // solve C*p = lambda*S*p, 
091                // equiv. to A*x = lambda*B*x (with A, B symmetric, B positive definite):
092                GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition eigen = 
093                                new GeneralizedSymmetricEigenDecomposition(C, S, 1e-15, 1e-15); 
094                
095                if (eigen.hasComplexEigenvalues()) {
096                        throw new RuntimeException("encountered complex eigenvalues");
097                }
098                
099                double[] evals = eigen.getRealEigenvalues();    
100                int k = Matrix.idxMax(evals);                                   // index of the largest eigenvalue
101                return eigen.getEigenvector(k).toArray();               // associated eigenvector       
102        }
103        
104}
